notes.text:
[**2151-11-27**] 12:26 PM
 CTA ABD W&W/O C & RECONS; CTA PELVIS W&W/O C & RECONS           Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 87372**]
 Reason: r/o aortic aneurysm or aortic dissection, colitis
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  85F p/w CP, abd pain radiating to back, N/V since yest. Asymmetric distal
  pulses.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  r/o aortic aneurysm or aortic dissection, colitis
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: LLTc SAT [**2151-11-27**] 1:46 PM
  1. No acute intraabdominal/intrapelvic process.
  2. 7 mm celiac aneurysm (5:32).
  3. No AAA.
  4. Normal appearing bowel.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  85-year-old female presenting with chest pain and abdominal pain
 radiating to the back, with nausea and vomiting since yesterday.  There is a
 concern for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

 No comparison studies available.

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT-acquired 5-mm axial images of the abdomen were obtained
 before and following the uneventful administration of 100 cc of Optiray
 intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittal reformats were performed at 5-mm
 slice thickness.

 FINDINGS:

 CTA:
 There are mild atherosclerotic calcifications throughout the abdominal aorta,
 which demonstrates normal caliber and patency throughout its course.  Moderate
 atherosclerotic calcifications are seen within the iliac branches, with no
 evidence of significant stenosis.  On primary image reconstructions there was
 suggestion of a 7-mm aneurysm at the celiac artery near the takeoff of the
 left gastric and common hepatic arteries (5:32), but on 3D reformations and
 volume renderings (series 450-452), this appears to be an ectatic rather than
 an aneurysmal segment.  The SMA is widely patent and normal in caliber,
 demonstrating multiple segmental and subsegmental branches which opacify with
 contrast.  The [**Female First Name (un) 85**] is patent.  A small left accessory renal artery is seen
 (5:43).  A small atherosclerotic plaque rises from the takeoff of the right
 main renal artery (5:39), however, patent distal flow is seen and the kidneys
 appear to enhance symmetrically.

 ABDOMEN:
 Included views of the lungs demonstrate mild dependent atelectasis.  The heart
 size is normal.  There is no pericardial or pleural effusion.  Lipomatosis of
 the interatrial septum is present (2:1).  There are mild atherosclerotic
 calcifications of the coronary vessels and aortic valve.

                                                             (Over)

 [**2151-11-27**] 12:26 PM
 CTA ABD W&W/O C & RECONS; CTA PELVIS W&W/O C & RECONS           Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 87372**]
 Reason: r/o aortic aneurysm or aortic dissection, colitis
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 The liver, spleen, adrenal glands, kidneys, pancreas, stomach, and
 intra-abdominal loops of small and large bowel are within normal limits.
 Scattered prominent mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph nodes do not meet CT
 criteria for lymphadenopathy.  There is no free air or free fluid.

 PELVIS:
 The rectum appears normal.  There is moderate colonic diverticulosis, with no
 evidence of diverticulitis.  The uterus appears normal, containing a coarse
 calcification (5:124) which is most compatible with a fibroid.  No adnexal
 masses are detected.  There is a small amount of pelvic free fluid (5:119).  A
 pessary device is appropriately postioned (5:136).  A Foley catheter
 terminates appropriately within a partially collapsed bladder.  There is no
 intrapelvic lymphadenopathy.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:
 There is no acute fracture or dislocation.  No concerning blastic or lytic
 lesions are identified.  Mild multilevel degenerative changes are present
 throughout the thoracic and lumbar spine, including mild multilevel facet
 arthropathy from L3 through L5.

 3D reformations were created in the Imaging Lab to support these findings.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  No AAA or acute aortic process.
 2.  Ectatic celiac axis origin without discrete aneurysm.
 3.  No acute intra-abdominal process seen.

notes.text:
[**2151-11-30**] 11:01 AM
 CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST                                           Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 87373**]
 Reason: SIADH, ?malignancy
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPONATREMIA
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  85 year old woman with h/o CAD, HTN p/w hyponatremia, gram + bacteremia
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  SIADH, ?malignancy
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  85-year-old female with history of coronary artery disease,
 hypertension, gram-positive bacteremia, presenting with hyponatremia, evaluate
 for SIADH.

 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph [**2151-11-27**] and CTA abdomen [**2151-11-27**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast chest CT was performed using MDCT.  Both axial 5- and
 1.25-mm collimation images, as well as a series of multiplanar reformatted
 images, were reviewed.

 CT CHEST WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  There is no supraclavicular, axillary, or
 mediastinal lymphadenopathy.  Several coronary arteries have been stented.
 The aortic valve is mildly calcified.  There is lipomatous hypertrophy of ther
 interatrial septum.

 FINDINGS:  The trachea and bronchi are patent to subsegmental levels.  There
 is minimal subsegmental atelectasis at the lung bases but no focal
 consolidation or mass.  A pulmonary nodule in the right middle lobe measures 3
 mm in bidirectional measurements (4:106) requiring no further action [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
 [**Last Name (un) 911**] guidelines.  Additional tiny subcentimeter calcified nodules are
 benign.

 The upper abdomen is partially imaged and appears unremarkable, as do osseous
 structures.

 IMPRESSION:  Minimal subsegmental atelectasis.  No evidence of malignancy or
 infection.

Hyponatremia

History of Present Illness:
Mrs. [**Known lastname **] is an 85 year old female with a PMH significant for
CAD s/p PCI, HTN, and HLD admitted for hyponatremia. The patient
and her daughters report that she has had decreased PO intake
over the past week, and yesterday developed nausea and vomiting.
Her daughters further state that she was admitted to NEBH one
month prior for "dehydration," but she did not have a low
sodiuum level at that time. They further state that since her
discharge, she has had an acute decline in her memory and
ability to function independently, and is currently living at
home with her husband under 24 hour nursing care.  She denies
any f/c/s, diarrhea, chest pain, shortness of breath, HA,
palpitations, orthopnea, LE edema, or PND. The patient does
report a periumbilicar abomdinal pain, which her daughters state
has been going on for years.  Her daughters also state that she
has had no recent medication changes.
.
In the [**Hospital1 18**] ED, initial VS 77 115/55 20 100%RA.  A CXR and UA
was negative. A CTAP demonstrated a 7 mm celiac aneurysm, for
which vascular surgery was consulted in the ED with
recommendation for no acute intervention at this time. The
patient was then admitted to the MICU for further management.
.
Currently, the patient is resting comfortably without
complaints.

Past Medical History:
Bradycardia
Labile hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Cholecystectomy
Bilateral cataract surgery
Acid reflux
Coronary artery disease, s/p PCI to LAD, LCX and RCA
COPD/asthma (not an active problem)
Glaucoma
Appendectomy
Tonsillectomy
Eczema on legs bilaterally

Social History:
Married, lives at home with her husband, independent prior to
admission


Family History:
Non-contributory

Physical Exam:
VS: 97.7 87 173/78 21 100%RA
Gen: Elderly frail woman in NAD
HEENT: Dry MM, PERRL, eomi, sclerae anicteric. No LAD
CV: Nl S1+S2, JVP flat
Pulm: CTAB
Abd: S/NT/ND +bs
Ext: No c/c/e.
Neuro: AOx3, CN II-XII intact.

On discharge:
VS: 97.8 156/90 92 16 97% RA
Gen: Elderly frail woman in NAD, AOx3
HEENT: mmm, PERRL, eomi, sclerae anicteric. No LAD
CV: Nl S1+S2, JVP flat
Pulm: CTAB

Pertinent Results:

3. No acute intra-abdominal process seen.

CXR: No acute intrathoracic process.

of SIADH.

malignancy or
infection.

Admission labs:

Discharge labs:
[**2151-12-3**] 09:50AM BLOOD WBC-8.6 RBC-3.86* Hgb-10.7* Hct-32.4*
MCV-84 MCH-27.8 MCHC-33.0 RDW-16.4* Plt Ct-329
[**2151-12-3**] 09:50AM BLOOD Glucose-173* UreaN-11 Creat-0.5 Na-132*
K-3.9 Cl-97 HCO3-28 AnGap-11


Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. [**Known lastname **] is an 85 year old female with a PMH significant for
CAD s/p PCI, HTN, and HLD admitted for hyponatremia.

# Hyponatremia: The patient was admitted with a serum sodium of
113, but without seizure activity or evidence of coma,
suggesting that patient's sodium decreased slowly over time.
However her mental status was not at baseline, very likely [**12-29**]
delirium in the setting of hyponatremia.  Her thiazide diuretic
was held, as this was likely contributing to hyponatremia.  On
admission, she was noted to be hypovolemic and her sodium
improved some with normal saline.  However, her sodium started
to decrease with continued normal saline infusion.  Urine and
serum lytes were rechecked and in the setting of euvolemia, her
hyponatremia was thought most likely to be due to SIADH (urine
osm >400, serum Na <120 and serum osms low, and urine Na
inappropriately high).  CT head and chest were done to eval for
malignancy for etiology of SIADH, no masses were noted.  She was
treated with free water restriction and TID salt tabs, as
recommended by the nephrology service.  On discharge she will
continue to take salt tabs and have her Na monitored as an
outpatient.  Na on discharge 132.  She will f/u with PCP for
another [**Name9 (PRE) **] check on [**12-7**].  She should probably not restart a
thiazide diuretic in the future.

#Altered mental status: likely has baseline dementia that
initially was slowly progressing but acutely worsened after
being hospitalized in [**Month (only) **].  Has 24 hr nursing care at home.
 During admission initially, was frequently not oriented to
place or location, or why she was in the hospital and often saw
people and things that were not actually present, with both
auditory and visual hallucinations.  Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 688**] course
suggested delirium in the setting of her hyponatremia vs
worsening dementia.  On discharge, mental status at baseline per
family, unable to do months of the year backwards but AOx3 and
no hallucinations.  continued home aricept.

# HTN: Her hydrochlorothiazide was held as above.  She was
continued on valsartan at 160 mg [**Hospital1 **], which is her home dose.
She was also continued on isosorbide mononitrate.  SBP was still
elevated to 140s-160s, so amlodipine 5 mg daliy was started for
improved BP control.

# ?Celiac aneurysm: Initially CT Abd/pelvis showed concern for
celiac artery aneursym, however final CTA read ectatic celiac
artery without aneurysm.

# Elevated lipase: Unclear significance with no radiographic
evidence of pancreatic and benign abdominal exam.  Also had CTA
abd/pelvis without evidence of pancreatitis.

# CAD s/p PCI: She was continued on ASA, valsartan, and
clopidogrel.

# DM 2: HISS with accuchecks, continued home metformin on
discharge.

# HLD: Vytorin continued on discharge.

Code: DNR/DNI (confirmed with daughters/[**Name2 (NI) **]-HCPs during admission

day).

Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day.
14. Trusopt 2 % Drops Sig: One (1)  Ophthalmic twice a day: 1
drop both eyes [**Hospital1 **].
15. Vytorin [**9-14**] 10-20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a
day.


Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service

Facility:
Bayada VNA

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hyponatremia
Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone
(SIADH)
Hypertension


Discharge Condition:
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.


Discharge Instructions:
You were seen in the hospital for hyponatremia, which is a low
level of sodium in your blood.  This may have been caused by
decreased eating and drinking at home, and also by a hormone in
your body that was holding on to too much water in the blood
stream and diluting the sodium in your blood.

Please continue taking salt tablets three times a day and
restricting free water intake.  This means limiting the intake
of plain water, juice, tea, and other fluids like this to one
liter per day.  Liquids such as gatorade, soup, supplement
shakes, and others that have a higher content of salt and
electrolytes are not limited.  Please continue limiting free
water to 1 liter per day unless directed otherwise by your PCP,
[**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**Last Name (STitle) **].

We also stopped your hydrochlorothiazide, which may have been
contributing to the low sodium level in your blood.  To control
your blood pressure, we started a new medication, amlodipine,
for blood pressure control.

Changes to your medications:
STOP taking hydrochlorothiazide
STOP taking clonidine

START taking amlodipine daily
START taking salt tablets (sodium chloride) three times a day
with meals

notes.text:
[**2151-11-30**] 11:01 AM
 CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 85640**]
 Reason: SIADH, ?malignancy
 Admitting Diagnosis: HYPONATREMIA
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  85 year old woman with h/o CAD, HTN p/w hyponatremia, gram + bacteremia
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  SIADH, ?malignancy
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): SZm [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2019**] [**2151-11-30**] 2:56 PM
  PFI:  No evidence of intracranial mass or lesion to suggest the patient's
  SIADH.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  SIADH, question of underlying malignancy.

 COMPARISON:  No prior.

 TECHNIQUE:  CT of the head without IV contrast.  There is no evidence of any
 intracranial masses.  In particular, there is no evidence of any suprasellar
 mass to suggest the cause of patient's underlying SIADH.  Note is made of
 diffuse periventricular hypodensities consistent with small vessel ischemic
 disease.  Otherwise, the ventricle and sulci are appropriate for the patient's
 age.  The patient has had prior lung surgery.

 Findings consistent with vascular territory infarct.

 There is no evidence of fracture.  Paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are
 unremarkable with no fluid.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No evidence of intracranial mass to suggest a source of SIADH.
 2.  No acute intracranial process.

 INDICATION:  85-year-old female with chest pain and abdominal pain.

 COMPARISON:  None available.

 TWO VIEWS OF THE CHEST:

 The lungs are well expanded and clear.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette,
 hilar contours, and pleural surfaces are normal.  No pleural effusions or
 pneumothoraces are present.  There is mild degenerative change with anterior
 osteophyte formation of the mid thoracic spine.
